lessonObjectives:
• Identify some of the common pollutants found in the New York Harbor estuary.
  • Plan, diagram and design a filter that removes certain “pollutants” from the water
  • Compare the functioning of their filter to the functioning of an oyster
background:
According to NOAA and the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, a single Eastern Oyster (crassostrea virginica) can filter up to 50 gallons of water a day.  
Oysters are filter feeders, which means they eat by pumping large volumes of water through their body. In order to eat, oysters open their shells slightly, exposing the little hairlike structures on their gills, called cilia.  The oyster moves these cilia in a wavelike motion creating a localized water current, thereby drawing the water inward and over the gills.  This process both ventilates the oysters gills for respiration and captures particles that the oyster will eat. The exact mechanism of particle capture is a complex one, and is accomplished in two different ways: the hydrodynamic mechanism draws in particles through the movement of water; and the mucociliary mechanism uses cilia structures and mucous to capture particles. Particles removed from suspension by these two mechanisms are transported along the gills to the labial palps.

<INSERT PIC>
see - https://docs.google.com/document/d/1QUGOqmb2wlQ9AWb05xI4LuyisyQa7bUsYyhEYTZj9tI/edit

The mechanism by which oysters and other bivalves differentiate between different types of particles is not well understood. The labial palps are able to sort and select individual particles, moving the algae, food and nutrients towards the esophagus, while all other non-nutritious particles become pseudofeces and expelled before going into the digestive system.  
Most of the particles filtered by oysters are about 1-10 microns in diameter, approximately the same size as the single-celled phytoplankton (algae) that make up most of their diet. Some of the food particles are also ejected as pseudofeces without passing through the gut, because oysters need to ventilate their gills for more time than they need to feed.

instructionPlan.evaluate: Students work either individually or in their groups complete the “Machine vs Nature” section of the worksheet.
instructionPlan.elaborate: Students calculate how their filter compares to an oyster (#7 and #8 on worksheet).
instructionPlan.explain: Once all filters have been tested bring all the beakers up to the font of the classroom and facilitate a discussion comparing and contrasting the results.  Solicit from students which materials they chose to use and how they used them.  Solicit from students what worked well and what they would do differently next time.
instructionPlan.explore:
1. Separate students into small groups.
  2. Hand out a “Can You Out-Filter an Oyster?” worksheet to each student.
  3. Review activity directions/rules (you may want to add more of these rules to the “Directions” section of the worksheet:
  4. Use as few or as many materials as you choose.
  5. Materials may be altered (e.g. rip the sponge in half).
  6. The teacher will pour the estuary solution through each filter so the pouring is consistent and fair from group to group.
  7. Each filter is allowed to process the estuary solution for exactly one minute.
  8. You may not touch your filter in any way during the filtering (e.g. You may not press on the sponge to squeeze out the water).
  9. Use the colander as the foundation of your filter. Do not alter the colander in any way.
  10. The colander will sit in one aluminum tray, which will catch the water coming out of the filter. You will transfer the colander to the second aluminum tray at the end of one minute.  The liquid in the first aluminum tray will be poured into the 250mL beaker. Do not alter the trays in any way. 
  11. Create a “New York Harbor Estuary Solution” in front of the class.  Add ingredients one by one, soliciting from the class what happens to the ingredient in the water (dissolve, sink, suspend, float, etc.) and what the ingredient represents in real life.

INSERT TABLE

  1. Hand out one Filter Kit to each group and review the included materials.
  2. Give students about 15 minutes to design and build their filter.  Consider requiring groups to draw a preliminary sketch of their filter for approval before they are permitted to build it.  
  3. When a group finishes their filter make sure it is placed in one of the aluminum trays.
  4. Pour the Estuary Solution through the filter slowly and evenly making a spiral motion around the bottom of the colander.  Let the water drain through for exactly one minute.
  5. When one minute is up transfer the colander to the second aluminum tray (as it will continue to drip) and pour the contents of the first tray into the 250mL beaker.
  6. Put a piece of masking tape on the side of the beaker and write the filter name.
  7. Students begin to work on “Part IV: Analyzing Your Filter” of the worksheet.
instructionPlan.engage: Show the students one of the Oyster Filtration Youtube videos listed under Teacher Resources. Discuss as fits the needs of your class.

materialsResources.supplies:
Filter Kit Supplies
aluminum trays (approx 13”x9”) - 2 per group
colander - 1 per group
measuring cup - 1 per group
250 mL plastic beaker - 1 per group	

household materials for building filter
napkins
paper towels
sponges
coffee filters
gauze
cotton balls
cotton swabs
straws
masking tape


“New York Harbor Estuary Solution” Supplies
salt
potting soil (with styrofoam pieces)
cooking oil
dish soap
Chocolate Rice Krispy Treats
food coloring
materialsResources.teacherTips:
Activity works best with small groups of three or four students

“New York Harbor Estuary Solution” recipe (amounts are simply an approximate guide)

1 ½ cups water
¼ tsp salt
1 Tbs potting soil
1 tsp cooking oil
1 tsp dish soap
1 tsp Cocoa Krispies
1-2 drops food coloring

Prepare all the “New York Harbor Estuary Solutions” in advance except one to do as a demo in front of the class.

Prepare all Filter Kits in advance.
This activity is designed to have the students design, build and test the filter only once.  If you have the time, consider allowing the students to revise their design and build a second filter based on what they learned from the first test.

handoutsFileInput.originalname: Can You Out-Filter an Oyster Worksheet.docx

teacherResourcesLinks.name: “Oyster Filtration” Time-lapse YouTube video demonstrating oyster filtration.

lessonOverview.lessonSummary: Students will work in small groups to build a “filter” out of household materials and compete against other groups to see who can do the best job filtering the special mixture of “harbor estuary water” that the teacher creates for them.

title: Can you Out-Filter an Oyster?

lessonObjectives:
1. Students will look at a table of tides and think about how to scale an axis and graph
  2. Students will create a graph of a tide chart that is relevant to their restoration station.
  3. Students will learn about discrete versus continuous data and independent versus dependent variables.
  4. Students can apply their knowledge to decipher and understand maps.
background:
The lesson is designed to focus specifically on the skills necessary for graphing: scaling axes, discrete and continuous data, and independent and dependent variables, as well as creating the graphs themselves.

The lesson will allow students to use the Eldridge Tide Charts and maps to practice graphing skills, interpreting graphs, and classifying data. Eldridge Tide Charts are a nautical resource that have been used since 1875 to pilot boats through all harbors on the eastern seaboard. There are two components: tide charts that show high and low tides at specific locations, and maps that can be used to navigate the current based on the hours past from high tide. 

Students will first look at a tide chart. Once they have interpreted that tide chart, there is an extension involving a current map. The current map shows the direction and speeds of currents at a specific time before or after high tide. The final extension of the lessons allows the students to explore one of these tide maps.

instructionPlan.elaborate:
OPTIONAL EXTENSION:Students can examine and complete a worksheet using a current map that refers to the tide charts. Explain to the students that boat pilots use the tide chart in conjunction with this map to interpret the current direction and speed at any given moment. This activity also provides an opportunity for basic map reading. Label the four cardinal directions on the map with the students and then have them complete the rest of the activity.

OPTIONAL READING FOR DISCUSSION: http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/moon-life-tides/
instructionPlan.explain: Students will compare graphs and complete data analysis questions. If necessary, students can also complete the “Dependent Versus Independent” and “Discrete Versus Continuous” handouts in order to further understand the data they are analyzing. These handouts focus on different aspects of the restoration station and can be a springboard for further conversation about the restoration station.
instructionPlan.explore: Tell students that this lesson is designed to practice their graphing skills. Students will complete the “Create a Tide Chart Handout” using the May/June 2014 High and Low Water tides at The Battery, NY Harbor. They will graph the date of the month versus tide data for the first 17 days in May.
instructionPlan.engage:
Show this film at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qvzc9yF3g6c

Show the film at it’s opening and at about 1:55

Ask the students to make observations.

Questions for discussion: 

  • What is the difference that you see at the two points in the movies?
  • What causes this change?
  • Why are tides important?
  • What is the difference between the beach at high tide and at low tide?
  • Why do you think tides are important to marine life?

materialsResources.supplies:
Graph paper
Rulers
PENCILS
Projector for Film

Eldridge Tide chart: The Battery, May/June 2014
Eldridge Map: 2 Hours after High Tide at the Battery
materialsResources.teacherTips:
The backbone of the lesson is graphing a tide chart. The other handouts: “Discrete Versus Continuous” and “Dependent and Independent” are designed to provide background content while simultaneously introducing students to some of the vocabulary of the restoration station.
The Map extension activity requires some knowledge of geography. If your students do not know the cardinal directions, it is worth doing the Geography lesson first.

lessonOverview.lessonSummary: This lesson asks students to look at a tide chart from the Eldridge Tide chart book. They will practice scaling their axes, creating a tide chart, and discussing how to classify tide data.There are also extensions to focus on discrete and continuous data as well as independent and dependent variables. Finally, they can explore an Eldridge Map to learn more about NYC geography.

title: Create a Tide Chart

lessonObjectives:
• What is density?
  • How do we find the density of a substance? 
  • Why is the idea of density important to study oysters?
background:
An adult oyster can filter up to 5 liters or 1.3 gallons on water an hour. That’s equal to 60 two-liter soda bottles a day, for just one oyster!  Historically, oysters could filter the Chesapeake Bay’s entire water volume in less than a week.  Today, with 1% of the oyster population left in the Chesapeake Bay, it would take oysters nearly a year.

Oysters are filter feeders, meaning they eat by pumping large volumes of water through their body.  Water is pumped over the oyster’s gills through the beating of cilia.  Plankton, algae and other particles become trapped in the mucus of the gills.  From there these particles are transported to the oyster esophagus and stomach to be eaten and digested.

Once the oyster removes all nutrients, indigestible material is expelled as “pseudofeces” through the anus.  The pseudofeces are expelled from the oyster’s shell via a rapid closing of valves. The expelled particles swirl through the water and resemble a smoke ring.  These smoke rings are an indication that oysters are filtering the water and doing what they are meant to do. (http://baybackpack.com/blog/how_does_an_oyster_filter_water)

instructionPlan.evaluate:
Which of the following objects from the harbor do you think will be discarded and which will be food for the oyster?

  1. Algae
  2. Sewage
  3. Plankton
  4. Small pieces of plastic
  5. Bacteria

Explain how density is important to the filtration that oysters do.
instructionPlan.elaborate: If oyster shells are more dense than water, they will sink. Why is this important? Explain that oysters absorb all particles in the water to “eat” them. They then release any non-digestible pieces from the water as pseudofeces. Due to the density of pseudofeces, these then sink into the benthic layer below and no longer pollute the water. This is how oysters filter.
instructionPlan.explain:
There are two options for this section:

OPTION 1:
Pass out the “Density Lab” handout. 

  1. Define density: Mass/Volume. Define Mass and Volume. 
  2. Find the density of each object. Find the mass by weighing the object and the volume by seeing how much water it displaces in the graduated cylinder.
  3. Calculate the density of each object.
  4. Test your hypothesis
  5. Discuss WHY an object would float or sink based on the density of water. 

OPTION 2: (much shorter)
  1. Define density: Mass/Volume. Define Mass and Volume. 
  2. Tell students the densities of the three substances: Oysters: 1.5-2 g/mL Candle Wax: .93 g/mL Rock: This varies based on the type. 2.3-5 g/mL (for an exact answer, look up the kind of rock you have or calculate the density)
  3. Tell students that the density of water is 1 g/mL. Ask them to hypothesize based on the densities which will float and which will sink. 
  4. Have them test their hypothesis in a beaker of water. Finally, discuss WHY an object would float or sink based on the density of water.
instructionPlan.explore:
Explain that the way the oysters filter the water has to do with density and that students will do a density lab to explore it.
Show the students the candle, rock and oyster shell. Ask the students to make a hypothesis. Which objects do they think will float and which do they think will sink? Ask them WHY an object would float or sink?
instructionPlan.engage:
Watch this movie
http://twistedsifter.com/2014/10/two-tanks-filled-with-same-water-one-has-oysters/

or

http://sploid.gizmodo.com/video-oysters-are-fantastic-at-filtering-dirty-water-1652540034

Why do you think the oyster water is so much clearer than the water without oysters? What do you think the oysters are doing?

materialsResources.supplies:
Beaker of water
Piece of a candle
Small rock
Oyster Shell
Scale
Graduated cylinders
materialsResources.teacherTips:
If your time is limited, rather than calculating density, you can simply give the students the densities of the objects and have them see if they float or sink and use the densities to explain. See OPTION 2 in the Explain section and use the OPTION 2 Handout.

Make sure your graduated cylinders are wide enough to drop the objects in so that you can see how much water they displace. 

For the object that floats (the candle), the students will need to push the candle until it is just submerged in order to calculate the volume. You can use a pencil for this.

If students struggle with ratios, there is an ratio and proportions practice sheet with oyster connections that might be fun.

teacherResourcesLinks.name: Two Tanks Filled with the Same Water but One has Oysters In It
Video: Oysters are fantastic at filtering dirty water

lessonOverview.lessonSummary: Students will watch a video of oysters filtering a tank to motivate their work. They will then do a lab where they will investigate which objects float and which objects do not. They will use that demonstration to discuss how oysters filter water.

title: Density Lesson

lessonObjectives:
• Students will decide which data is important and why
  • Students will graph data over time.
background: This lesson provides a basic introduction to the idea that not all data is relevant. It encourages students to consider what data is useful for analysis and when data does not answer any questions. It is an introduction to teaching students to consider large quantities of data and choosing their focus.

instructionPlan.evaluate: Decide which data your group will focus on next time you go to the oyster site. Why have you chosen that data? Justify your answer.
instructionPlan.explain: Discuss with students that not all the data that you collect at your restoration station will be relevant. Have them give examples of data that might not matter. Discuss what makes GOOD data and what data is not worth looking at (change over time, etc.)
instructionPlan.explore: Put the data from the worksheet (or any other set of data from your restoration station--see spreadsheet in this folder for more data) on the board or on a projector. Ask the students to discuss in groups which columns of data show change over time and which do not. Once they have decided that, hand out the “Graphing the Oysters!” worksheet and have the students work on it.
instructionPlan.engage: Examine the two graphs on the handout “Tigers and Wolves.” The handout asks students to compare a graph with only two pieces of data and one that is more complex and contains four pieces of data.

materialsResources.supplies:
Graph Paper
Rulers
Data Tables
Data
Projector/Document camera to display data
materialsResources.teacherTips:
This lesson can be done with any set of data from your restoration station. The one I included has obvious examples of relevant and irrelevant data, but you should definitely use your own data or any other data that your students are excited about. 

The opening worksheet could take an entire class or could be completed quickly. It all depends on how deeply you want your students to investigate. If you take a period with it, then this lesson will take two class periods. 

In this folder, there is a spreadsheet with more data (oysterrawdata.xlsx). Feel free to draw from that as well.

lessonOverview.lessonSummary: This lesson starts with students comparing two graphs, one which includes only two pieces of information and one that includes four. The students will compare and discuss the difference.  Then, students will examine a set of oyster data to determine which columns provide relevant data and why data is relevant or irrelevant. They will then create a graph showing the data over time.

title: Introduction to Data Analysis

lessonObjectives:
• What is density?
  • How can the same quantity of a substance feel “heavier”?
background: This lab introduces them to the idea, that certain substances are more dense than others. Density is a characteristic property of a substance. The density of a substance is the relationship between the mass of the substance and how much space it takes up (volume). The mass of atoms, their size, and how they are arranged determine the density of a substance. The concept of density is essential to understanding how oysters filter. This lesson introduces density. The next lesson in the folder applies density directly to oysters.

instructionPlan.elaborate: Write the name of every substance on the board. Ask for student hypotheses about the density rankings. Once students have proposed a hypothesis, rank the substances by the actual densities calculated by the students. Then, collect the samples and pour them into a large graduated cylinder with the most dense on the bottom (see picture on the next page)
instructionPlan.explain: Introduce the formula for density. Explain that density is mass over volume (or how “heavy” something is divided by the space it takes up. In other words, how compact a substance is). This is a good time to remind students of the difference between mass and weight. Mass is the amount of matter, whereas weight is the gravitation pull that the earth exerts on an object. However, it is worth explaining that in this lesson, you are weighing your substance to find the mass.Use the density calculation handout to have each group find the density of their substance.
instructionPlan.explore:
Divide your class into five groups. Give each group 10 mL of one of the following substances and a scale.  

  • ethanol
  • dishwashing detergent (doesn’t matter the brand, but should be colored)
  • dark corn syrup
  • vegetable oil
  • Water (colored blue) 

Make sure to write the weight of the graduated cylinder on the board so that the students can subtract that from their total weight.
instructionPlan.engage: Pass out graduated cylinders that hold 50 mL of molasses and 50 mL of alcohol. The graduated cylinders must be the same size. Ask students to make observations about the two liquids. Focus on the observation that the molasses is “heavier” (has more mass) than the alcohol. There is an observation chart included.

materialsResources.supplies:
1 large graduated cylinder (100 mL) (for the class)
5 10 mL graduated cylinder 
ethanol
dishwashing detergent (doesn’t matter the brand, but should be colored like Dawn lemon)
dark corn syrup
vegetable oil
water
4 50 mL cylinders, two full of molasses and two full of alcohol (enough for the whole class to pass around, you might want to make 3 of each)
materialsResources.teacherTips:
This lesson is structured as a jigsaw. Each group will compute the density of one substance and then the teacher will create the density column for the whole class. The reason for this is that it is very difficult for students to create a density column. If you get any materials on the side of the cylinder, the column will not look good. 
Make sure to practice the density column in advance. It helps to use a funnel to pour the substances in. 
Make sure the water is colored so that you can see that it is a different substance. For example, if your dish detergent is yellow, use blue for the water. 
In this lesson, we use the ideas of weight and mass interchangeably. Make sure students are clear on the difference before plunging in.

lessonOverview.lessonSummary: Students will compare various substances and discuss the difference between mass and volume. This will lead them to a discussion of density. The class will then jigsaw and each group will find the density of one substance. Then, the teacher will do a demo where she creates a density column and the class can see how different liquids of different densities behave.

title: Density Lesson

lessonObjectives:
1. Summarize how an oyster filters different types of particles out of the water.
  2. Design a filter based on certain parameters and constraints.
  3. Critique their filter design and plan for improvements.

instructionPlan.evaluate: Design a filter that can specifically filter detergents out of the water..
instructionPlan.elaborate: Watch the following Science Friday video “Blue Whale Barrel Roll.” What clues does it give you for how to move your filter to get the most food? Do you think these tips apply to all filter feeders or just swimming ones?
instructionPlan.explain: Show students the Filter Feeder Slideshow and videos.   Explain the details of how an oyster filters the water.
instructionPlan.explore:
• Get into a group of 2-3 students.
  • Get a Filter Feeder Worksheet.  Fill out your worksheet as you go through the activity (not at the end).
  • Sort through the supplies for making the filter.
  • Think about the size of the holes in the cup and the size of the food particles.  Some parts of your filter may actually catch food particles, while other parts of your filter may steer or direct food particles in a certain direction.
  • Decide which materials you will use to create your filter.
  • Make the filter!  Sketch and label the filter on your worksheet.
  • Put the rice in the test tank and mix it around.
  • Run your filter around the test tank for 20 seconds.  Collect as many pieces of rice in your filter as possible.  
  • Count the rice and return it to the tank.
  • Make modifications on your filter.  You can add, subtract or reinforce materials.  You CANNOT get a new cup.
  • Make another 20 second run of your filter around the test tank.
  • Count the rice and return it to the tank.
  • Compare Run #1 and Run #2.  
  • Answer other questions on the Filter Feeder Worksheet.
instructionPlan.engage:
If you were to create your own marine filter, what would it look like? How would you build it? What filters do we use in our everyday lives?  

To help inspire you, we’ve highlighted some of the filtration structures and mechanisms used by marine filter feeders:

<INSERT PIC> - https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-d6DzJf5jLtjZlHTOYE7hIhDbXJwkxPLCMhAOCeR5lE/edit


  • Pores – holes of varying size that allow water to exit the filter. Only particles smaller than the pore are able to pass through
  • Cilia – tiny, flexible hairs that collect small food particles and transport them to a collection area
  • Branches – forked structures, like tree branches or feathers, with high surface area that are passed through the water to capture food particles
  • Mucous – gooey coating that makes the filter or filter structures sticky, capturing particles it comes into contact with
  • Combs – rods with ridged, narrow teeth (just like a hair comb!) that stick out into the flow of water, trapping particles that are too large to fit between the teeth

materialsResources.supplies:
Plastic cups (one for each group with holes cut in the bottom)
Filter-making supplies
feathers, pipe cleaners, mesh, screen, string, fabric, lace, those pieces of fake grass that you find in sushi containers, glue
Filter-building supplies
scissors, tape, stapler, paper clips, binder clips, glue
Rice (uncooked)
Test tank (any kind of tank or bin will do)
water
timer/stopwatch
materialsResources.teacherTips:
Since this lesson involves water be sure to have clean-up supplies on hand.
Don’t use supplies that will get ruined when wet (e.g. paper, cotton balls, etc.)

lessonOverview.lessonSummary: Students will design their own filter out of household items to see how many food particles they can filter out of the water.

title: Filter Feeder

lessonObjectives:
• Describe the movement of water through the water cycle
  • Understand that water changes states when it gains energy from the sun or loses energy to the environment
  • Understand that gravity causes water to move downhill and to precipitate from the clouds
  • Create a model of the water cycle using the original pictures of water in the act of precipitating, infiltrating, condensing, running off, evaporating and transpiring.
background:
The water cycle has no starting point. But, we'll begin in the oceans, since that is where most of Earth's water exists. The sun, which drives the water cycle, heats water in the oceans. Some of itevaporates as vapor into the air. Ice and snow cansublimate directly into water vapor. Rising air currents take the vapor up into theatmosphere, along with water fromevapotranspiration, which is water transpired from plants and evaporated from the soil. The vapor rises into the air where cooler temperatures cause it tocondense into clouds.
 
Air currents move clouds around the globe, cloud particles collide, grow, and fall out of the sky asprecipitation. Some precipitation falls as snow and can accumulate asice caps and glaciers, which can store frozen water for thousands of years. Snowpacks in warmer climates often thaw and melt when spring arrives, and the melted water flows overland assnowmelt.
 
Most precipitation falls back into the oceans or onto land, where, due to gravity, the precipitation flows over the ground assurface runoff. A portion of runoff enters rivers in valleys in the landscape, withstreamflow moving water towards the oceans. Runoff and groundwater seepage accumulate and arestored as freshwater in lakes. Not all runoff flows into rivers [and lakes], though. Much of it soaks into the ground asinfiltration. Some water infiltrates deep into the ground and replenishesaquifers (saturated subsurface rock), which store huge amounts of freshwater for long periods of time.
 
 
Some infiltration stays close to the land surface and can seep back into surface-water bodies (and the ocean) asgroundwater discharge, and some groundwater finds openings in the land surface and emerges as freshwatersprings. Over time, though, all of this water keeps moving, some to re-enter the ocean, where the water cycle "ends" ... oops - where it "begins."
 
Source: http://water.usgs.gov/edu/watercyclehi.html


<INSERT PIC> - https://docs.google.com/document/d/1gvHArl-ITiVxs95X-VSI8cGxzhaEnySC5LMHRXku9Mw/edit

Source: http://www.sswm.info/category/implementation-tools/wastewater-collection/hardware/surface-runoff/stormwater-management

instructionPlan.evaluate:
• Students will create a New York City Water Cycle model utilizing their photographs. Students can complete this portion of the lesson with either printed or digital copies of their photographs. Students can use PowerPoint, Prezi, or printed photographs and poster board to create their models. Each group should have one complete set of photographs to work with.
  • To begin, students label each photograph with the part of the water cycle (or human impact) it represents. This activity can serve as an evaluation of students’ comfort with water cycle vocabulary. 
  • Ask students to think about what makes water move through the water cycle. Why doesn’t the water just stay in the same state and in the same place forever? Give groups time to discuss amongst themselves. If students have a difficult time figuring out gravity and sunlight are responsible for water’s movement, show them a standard water cycle diagram and have them to look for clues.
  • Students’ water cycle models should include all parts of the water cycle (processes and “resting” places); show the multiple paths water takes through the water cycle in New York City; and convey the idea that gravity and energy from the sun drives water’s movement through the cycle.
instructionPlan.elaborate:
Students can take additional photos or create additional drawings at home in order to fill in any gaps in their water cycle.
  • Did we leave any parts of the water cycle out?
  • When water isn’t in the process of evaporating, condensing, etc., where is it? 
  • Identify the places water “rests”/is stored (harbor, rivers, puddles, clouds, plants, etc.) within the cycle.
  • Where do freezing (snow/glaciers) and melting fit in the water cycle?
  • Where do dew and fog fit in the water cycle?
  • Where does the water that the plants transpire come from? Should we include capillary action as a force in the water cycle?
instructionPlan.explain: This lesson is an opportunity to introduce or reinforce the concept of Combined Sewer Overflows (CSOs). Water that doesn’t evaporate or infiltrate becomes surface water runoff. Surface water may flow over the ground surface or enter storm drains.  Water captured by storm drains flows downhill through sewer pipes (downhill direction determined by the pipe orientation) into a wastewater treatment plant. Stormwater shares these pipes with raw sewage (also called the sanitary sewer). The stormwater is treated and then discharged into the nearest body of water. However, when the sewer system becomes overwhelmed with storm water, both the raw sewage and storm water flow directly into the nearest body of water through combined sewer overflow (CSO) outfalls.  This means that almost every time it rains we have raw sewage flowing into our harbor.
instructionPlan.explore:
1. Students will go outdoors and become water cycle sleuths. Students use a camera to capture water moving through the water cycle. For example, they are to catch water in the act of precipitating, running downhill, infiltrating, etc.
  2. Students will also photograph any human impacts on the water cycle.  For example, students could photograph (or possibly stage) litter that could get caught up in runoff.
  3. Ideally, students will have the opportunity to work outside on a day when it is raining, has just rained, or when snow is melting. If the weather is uncooperative, students can bring out water sprayers and buckets of water to simulate rain falling over different surfaces.
  4. Divide students into small groups. Give each group a camera and a Photograph Record Worksheet. 
  5. Go outdoors! Define the students’ work area. 
  6. Students work as a team to get the pictures they need and they fill out the Photograph Record Worksheet as they take each photograph. See examples below.

 
< INSERT PIC>
 http://justrightplumbingla.com/yard-and-parking-lot-drains/yard-and-parking-lot-drains/
 < INSERT PIC>
http://www.wallpapermania.eu/wallpaper/lost-of-water-drops-on-a-green-leaf-macro-hd-wallpaper

  1. Bring students back together. Ask the groups which part(s) of the water cycle they have been unable to photograph. 
  2. Brainstorm as a class how to obtain the images they need. For example, students may suggest drawing a picture or using photoshop to depict evaporation or transpiration. (See Teacher Resources for links to simple transpiration activities.)
instructionPlan.engage:
1. Ask students the following questions:
  2. What is precipitation?
  3. What types of precipitation are there? 
  4. What types of precipitation do we experience living here in NYC?
  5. Which state is water in for each type of precipitation you named?
  6. Divide students into small groups. Give each group a stack of sticky notes and colored markers (each group gets a different color to write with). 
  7. Groups brainstorm what happens to the precipitation that falls here. Where does the water go? How does it get there? 
  8. Students write each idea on a separate sticky note.
  9. Bring the class back together. 
  10. Project this image (or a similar image that shows a NYC scene with road, water, buildings and park) in front of the class.

<INSERT PIC>
http://www.reflectionsenroute.com/new-york-city-by-water/

  1. Facilitate groups/students coming up to the image and posting their sticky note on the photo. (e.g. “rain” could go in the sky, “runoff” could go by the edge of the dock, “infiltration” could go by the trees, etc.)
  2. Recap the students’ ideas. For example, “Rain falls onto the grass in the parks and infiltrates the soil.  Rain falls onto the street and runsoff the edge of the dock into the harbor.” Help the students understand that their sticky notes are all part of the water cycle.
  3. Have a set of water cycle sticky notes pre-written before class.  Fill in any gaps that the students missed (e.g. transpiration) and explain where it fits into the water cycle.

materialsResources.supplies:
sticky notes (one pad per group)
colored markers 
projector
cameras 
buckets of water (if weather is uncooperative)
water sprayers (if weather is uncooperative)
presentation software (e.g. Prezi, PowerPoint) OR
printed student photographs and poster board/paper
materialsResources.teacherTips:
Students will take their own photographs and then construct a water cycle diagram.  If you plan on printing out the pictures and having the students arrange them on posterboard, you could consider having groups of 4-5.  If the students will be using digital photographs arranged on something like Powerpoint or Prezi you should consider having students work in pairs.
Consider whether you want a standard water cycle diagram available for students to look at any point in this lesson.

teacherResourcesLinks.name: Plant Transpiration – Plants Sweat Too!!! (qualitative transpiration activity)

lessonOverview.lessonSummary: In this lesson, students will go outdoors to observe and document the water cycle in motion where they live. Students will also discover how they and their community impact not only the movement of water through the cycle, but also the water quality.

title: A New York City Water Cycle
